However, he made his first public demonstration of a true television system on January 26 is sometimes disputed that the correct date of this feat was on July 3rd 1928; however, there is some discrepancy here on dates. His system, though, did provide moving images, yet it was not all electronic;  Baird used a mechanical television system that captured and displayed live, monochrome images.

The system transmitted live, monochrome images and consisted of a scanning disk, an image dissector (for capturing live images from a scene), an amplifier, a cathode ray tube (CRT) display, and other supporting electronics. His early experiments also utilized a mechanical rotating disk to capture and display live images.

His invention, while being widely recognized as a key milestone in video transmission, faced intense scrutiny and criticism due to technical differences from what we would consider 'true' television (which later involved fully electronic systems like those of Philo Farnsworth and John Vibbard).
